Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Congo Rainfall Variability and Trends
Award.AbstractNarration:
Central African forests, the driest and second largest on Earth, have experienced a long-term drying trend. A recent study detected a widespread decline in forest photosynthetic capacity over the Congo Basin and attributed this large-scale decline, at least partially, to this drying trend. Persistent drought in the region could alter the Congolese forest composition and structure in a manner that might favor the spread of drought tolerant species and thus impact biodiversity, carbon storage, and the global water cycle. Understanding the nature and cause of this drought and assessing its impacts on the forests are of significant societal, environmental, and economic importance. Understanding of climatic variability in the Congo basin is greatly hindered by a lack of observations and resources due to political, economic and historical factors.

Under this project, a combination of observational and modeling studies will be undertaken to investigate the nature and cause of the Congo rainfall variability in the 20th century. The role of global sea surface temperatures will be examined. For the observational component, observations and reanalysis data will be utilized to identify major patterns and drivers of the variability. For the modeling component, the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) simulations and idealized climate model simulations will be examined to investigate the physical mechanisms for the Congo drought. The relative contribution of anthropogenic versus natural forcing on the observed rainfall decadal variability over the Congo Basin will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background

The Congolese rainforest, the second largest tropical rainforest on earth, has experienced a long-term drying trend since the 1980s while similar droughts are absent in other tropical rainforests, Tropical rainforests modulate regional and global climate via various biogeophysical and biogeochemical processes and feedbacks. Hence, understanding the nature and cause of the Congo?s long-term drought and assessing its impacts on the forests are of significant societal, economic and environmental importance.

 

Intellectual merit

This project investigated major factors controlling the long-term rainfall variability and trend over the Congo Basin using observations, satellite and reanalysis data, and climate model simulations. Major outcomes of the project include:

1) attribution of the Congo drought to the tropical Indo-Pacific seat surface temperature (SST) variations associated changes in atmospheric circulation and moist transport (Hua et al. 2016; 2018);

2) development and distribution of a new gauge-based precipitation data set over the data scarcity central equatorial Africa (Nicholson et al., 2018);

3) evaluation of the performance of various reanalysis products, satellite products, and climate models over equatorial Africa (Hua et al. 2018; 2019; Nicholson 2019);

4) documentation of increasing extent and intensity of thunderstorms observed over the Congo (Raghavendra et al., 2018);

5) analysis of the trends in tropical wave activities from 1980-2016 (Raghavendra et al., 2019);

6) documentation of lengthening dry season length over the Congo (Jiang et al. 2019);

7) detection and attribution of the changes in burned area of wildfires over Central Africa using machine learning techniques (Jiang et al., 2020);   

8) analysis of the long-term variability of rainfall and the influence of the Madden?Julian oscillation (MJO) in modulating rainfall and rainfall trends over the Congo rainforest (Raghavendra et al., 2020);

9) analysis of the trends in convection and thunderstorm activity and possible physical mechanisms using the G?lvez-Davison index over the Congo Basin (Alber et al., 2020);

10) quantification of the influence of tropical Indian Ocean on central African rainfall (Jiang et al., 2021).

 

Broader impacts

This project provided learning and training experience for a postdoc and three Ph.D. students. Scientific findings were disseminated at conferences and workshops, through peer-reviewed publications, and into our homepage and teaching materials. Research results have reached not only to the meteorological community, but also to the hydrological, paleoclimate, environmental science, and ecological communities. One potentially transformative result of this work is the development and distribution of a new gauge-based precipitation data set over the data scarcity central equatorial Africa (Nicholson et al., 2018). Hydrological research in the region has been impeded by an almost complete lack of recent gauge data for the Congo Basin, a fact that also makes the assessment of reanalyses, satellite products, and climate models in this region very difficult. This new dataset has allowed us to evaluate the performance of satellite products (Nicholson et al. 2019) and reanalysis products (Hua et al. 2019) in the region.

 

Publications

So far, this award has resulted in 12 peer-reviewed articles. Graduate students and postdoc are lead authors for 10 of the papers (see attached Fig. 1).

 

Examples of two representative papers

The long-term drought over Central Equatorial Africa (CEA) may reflect the large-scale response of the atmosphere to tropical sea surface temperature (SST) variations. The study of Hua et al. (2016, see attached Fig. 2) has attributed the Congo drought primarily to SST variations over Indo-Pacific associated with the enhanced and westward-extended tropical Walker circulation (the large-scale atmospheric east-west equatorial circulation). These changes tend to induce subsidence and decrease convection over the Congo Basin, which lead to the reduction in low-level moisture transport and rainfall across the area.

 

The study of Jiang et al. (2019; see attached Fig. 3) analyzed multiple independent precipitation and satellite-derived vegetation datasets and found a widespread, longer dry season during the boreal summer (June to August) over the central African rainforest. The length has increased between 6.4 and 10.4 days per decade from 1988 to 2013. Dry season length strongly influences tropical rainforest vegetation structure and composition and is largely determined by precipitation patterns. It is one of the most crucial climate limitations for sustaining a rainforest. Any large changes in rainfall seasonality that modifies the Congo?s dry season length and intensity can influence the tropical rainforest?s photosynthesis and productivity.
